{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3130567,"name":"CJ Hill","username":"CJ_Hill","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cj_hill/{size}/142363_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-20T16:29:02.426Z","cooked":"

Looking for tips on getting thin wall elevator tube (maxtube, versaframe, etc) cut to exact dimensions. Buying long stock is a bit more practical than buying exact lengths, and you need to be petty close to mate cut parts with elevator gussets. We basically have a band saw, slow speed cold cut saw, inexpensive router and mill.

From a fresh piece, it’s easy to cut just a bit long on a slow saw or band saw, then indicate the fresh end to zero with an edge finder and then use a 1/4" end mill with a 1.25" cutting length to get our exact length (taking into account the radius of the bit, of course). We’re taking off up to 50 thou per cut and it seems to make a great cut. Our final piece is exactly as intended.

After that first cut things get harder, because now we have a piece with two bad ends. As an amateur, I was thinking of just indicating the new zero with a center finder or No. 10 drill bit on the first good hole and then cutting both sides so the holes line up properly for the gussets.

Any tips to improve this - speed or quality? For instance, can we just cut through the entire 1x2 with the mill and skip the coarse cuts altogether (i.e. find a zero with a hole and take off the entire 0.25" width of the bit with one cut?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-01-20T16:30:57.521Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":66,"reads":255,"readers_count":254,"score":401.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":424040,"topic_slug":"tips-on-machining-elevator-tube-to-length","display_username":"CJ Hill","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":32094,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2429 mentor"},"post_url":"/t/tips-on-machining-elevator-tube-to-length/424040/1","custom_user_title":"2429 mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3130623,"name":"Patrick Freivald","username":"pfreivald","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/pfreivald/{size}/177405_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-20T17:36:15.635Z","cooked":"

How tight does your tolerance have to be? We usually just cut box tube with a chop saw.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-01-20T17:36:15.635Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":206,"readers_count":205,"score":71.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":424040,"topic_slug":"tips-on-machining-elevator-tube-to-length","display_username":"Patrick Freivald","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7547,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC Mentor at Large"},"post_url":"/t/tips-on-machining-elevator-tube-to-length/424040/2","custom_user_title":"FRC Mentor at Large","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3130631,"name":"John Hascall (he)","username":"john3928","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/john3928/{size}/143275_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-20T17:46:59.684Z","cooked":"
CJ_Hill:

After that first cut things get harder, because now we have a piece with two bad ends. As an amateur, I was thinking of just indicating the new zero with a center finder or No. 10 drill bit on the first good hole and then cutting both sides so the holes line up properly for the gussets.

This is probably the best process – fix the “bad end” first, then proceed as you would with a factory-fresh end.

CJ_Hill:

…can we just cut through the entire 1x2 with the mill and skip the coarse cuts altogether…

We generally would not do it this way. I don’t think it saves any time and I don’t like big mill cuts like that. We can generally get our rough cut on the bandsaw within 1/4" of the final dimension and then we’d mill (or lathe for round stock) from there.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-01-20T17:46:59.684Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":187,"readers_count":186,"score":52.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":424040,"topic_slug":"tips-on-machining-elevator-tube-to-length","display_username":"John Hascall (he)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46267,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Opinions expressed are mine only"},"post_url":"/t/tips-on-machining-elevator-tube-to-length/424040/3","custom_user_title":"Opinions expressed are mine only","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3130632,"name":"Naomi","username":"nedwards28","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nedwards28/{size}/7156_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-20T17:47:17.432Z","cooked":"

I guess this depends on what the most important parts of your design are. If you are concerned about having gussets line up and aren’t worried as much about tolerance on the ends of the tube we have used a #20 or #21 drill bit to find the center of the last hole. We did this recently when cutting tubes for our swerve module drive base where the lengths of the ends weren’t critical. And in this case, speed was prioritized over quality. The gussets will line up great and define the holes to be correct relative to the holes on the other parts. We just needed to make sure to tighten down bolts while it was square.

If you really need a tighter tolerance, the holes are too small for the typical center finder/wobblers we have so we used a test indicator. There are lots of videos online to show you how to indicate a hole on a mill. Unfortunately, if you don’t have the appropriate tooling and accessories to mount that, it can be problematic. I’m not sure how others set up their indicators without a mag or clamps.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-01-20T17:47:17.432Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":173,"readers_count":172,"score":34.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":424040,"topic_slug":"tips-on-machining-elevator-tube-to-length","display_username":"Naomi","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"/tag/20","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0},{"url":"/tag/21","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":21640,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"PTC/Onshape Senior Curriculum Development and EDU Product"},"post_url":"/t/tips-on-machining-elevator-tube-to-length/424040/4","custom_user_title":"PTC/Onshape Senior Curriculum Development and EDU Product","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3130633,"name":"CEF","username":"CEF","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/35a633/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-01-20T17:48:45.974Z","cooked":"

Miter saw. We use a blade for non-ferrous metal. We can’t get precision measured in thousandths of an inch, but you usually don’t need that – frequently it’s more important that pieces be of equal length than of a precise size. Equal length is easy – cut them at the same time.

(Note: lots of people use “Chop saw” to refer to Miter saws. )

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-01-20T17:50:27.570Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":159,"readers_count":158,"score":71.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":424040,"topic_slug":"tips-on-machining-elevator-tube-to-length","display_username":"CEF","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":7547,"username":"pfreivald","name":"Patrick Freivald","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/pfreivald/{size}/177405_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28649,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/tips-on-machining-elevator-tube-to-length/424040/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3130635,"name":"Patrick","username":"Patrick3357","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/patrick3357/{size}/169915_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-20T17:50:40.011Z","cooked":"

We have put bolts or locating pins into the holes in the tube and used edge finders to pick up two bolts then get a center point between the holes. That works well enough for anything we’ve needed in FRC, but a test indicator will get you a little better.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-01-20T17:50:40.011Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":151,"readers_count":150,"score":60.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":424040,"topic_slug":"tips-on-machining-elevator-tube-to-length","display_username":"Patrick","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52597,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Build mentor"},"post_url":"/t/tips-on-machining-elevator-tube-to-length/424040/6","custom_user_title":"Build mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3130636,"name":"Naomi","username":"nedwards28","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nedwards28/{size}/7156_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-20T17:50:51.037Z","cooked":"

Oh yeah +1 to chop saw/band saw. I forgot to mention we do that first. Then, we take it to mill if tighter tolerance is needed.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-01-20T17:50:51.037Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":144,"readers_count":143,"score":28.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":424040,"topic_slug":"tips-on-machining-elevator-tube-to-length","display_username":"Naomi","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":21640,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"PTC/Onshape Senior Curriculum Development and EDU Product"},"post_url":"/t/tips-on-machining-elevator-tube-to-length/424040/7","custom_user_title":"PTC/Onshape Senior Curriculum Development and EDU Product","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3130639,"name":"Patrick","username":"Patrick3357","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/patrick3357/{size}/169915_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-20T17:54:49.013Z","cooked":"

Number one suggestion: If you are using the holes in the tube for all your fasteners, then the exact length of your tube is almost never important, just make sure you have the right number of holes and your tubes aren’t too long and causing interference. If you really think about where you need the precision, you may find that the mill is rarely needed.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-01-20T17:54:49.013Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":132,"readers_count":131,"score":76.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":424040,"topic_slug":"tips-on-machining-elevator-tube-to-length","display_username":"Patrick","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52597,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Build mentor"},"post_url":"/t/tips-on-machining-elevator-tube-to-length/424040/8","custom_user_title":"Build mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3130641,"name":"kgzak","username":"kgzak","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kgzak/{size}/157079_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-20T17:57:28.401Z","cooked":"

This is basically how we do it. Just cut it to as close as possible to the right size without going over. If it’s slightly too short that’s fine, the gusset will still work.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-01-20T17:57:28.401Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":124,"readers_count":123,"score":29.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":424040,"topic_slug":"tips-on-machining-elevator-tube-to-length","display_username":"kgzak","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":52597,"username":"Patrick3357","name":"Patrick","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/patrick3357/{size}/169915_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":11043,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/tips-on-machining-elevator-tube-to-length/424040/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3130644,"name":"John Hascall (he)","username":"john3928","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/john3928/{size}/143275_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-20T17:58:13.896Z","cooked":"
CEF:

We can’t get precision measured in thousandths of an inch, but you usually don’t need that…

Boy, oh boy. We have DROs on the mills and lathes we use and so I’m constantly saying “we’re not a ten-thousandths shop”. But it doesn’t really take, they all want to see those 4 zeros. So there they are tippy-tapping on the wheel, moving it .0001" at a time.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-01-20T17:58:13.896Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":123,"readers_count":122,"score":24.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":424040,"topic_slug":"tips-on-machining-elevator-tube-to-length","display_username":"John Hascall (he)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46267,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Opinions expressed are mine only"},"post_url":"/t/tips-on-machining-elevator-tube-to-length/424040/10","custom_user_title":"Opinions expressed are mine only","reactions":[{"id":"laughing","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3130648,"name":"CJ Hill","username":"CJ_Hill","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cj_hill/{size}/142363_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-20T18:02:16.271Z","cooked":"

Within a few thou would be ideal. One thing about the chop saw is that it tends to compress the thin wall tube, especially around the pre-drilled holes. Not sure if there is a technique for that other than to use a support insert.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-01-20T18:02:36.762Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":119,"readers_count":118,"score":28.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":424040,"topic_slug":"tips-on-machining-elevator-tube-to-length","display_username":"CJ Hill","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":7547,"username":"pfreivald","name":"Patrick Freivald","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/pfreivald/{size}/177405_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":32094,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2429 mentor"},"post_url":"/t/tips-on-machining-elevator-tube-to-length/424040/11","custom_user_title":"2429 mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3130653,"name":"Patrick","username":"Patrick3357","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/patrick3357/{size}/169915_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-20T18:04:48.190Z","cooked":"

I have never run into this problem, you could try feeding slower.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-01-20T18:04:48.190Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":118,"readers_count":117,"score":23.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":424040,"topic_slug":"tips-on-machining-elevator-tube-to-length","display_username":"Patrick","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":32094,"username":"CJ_Hill","name":"CJ Hill","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cj_hill/{size}/142363_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52597,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Build mentor"},"post_url":"/t/tips-on-machining-elevator-tube-to-length/424040/12","custom_user_title":"Build mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3130657,"name":"Jon Stratis","username":"Jon_Stratis","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jon_stratis/{size}/2663_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-20T18:12:45.563Z","cooked":"

We’ve always just cut ours with a horizontal bandsaw - nice straight cut, carefully measured, is generally close enough. The nice thing about the pre-drilled tubing is you don’t necessarily need to be exact, since the gusset plates or tube caps will align everything for you based on those predrilled holes. You only run into a problem if it’s slightly too long, in which case you can take a little more off.

In cases where we need two pieces to be the exact same length, like in an elevator, we clamp or bolt the two pieces together and cut them together. It’s always been close enough so far!

Freud Diablo non-ferrous metals blade on a dialed in miter saw will get you within .010 easily, .005 if you’re careful about it. You’ll want to get a steel rule graduated in 100ths to measure with.

I don’t know if this is “best” machining practice, but our team goes within a 1/8 inch over the desired length with a band or chop saw, then belt sands the rest of it: its quick and gets us the accuracy that we need.
